block.p: WILLIAMSBURG Friday Night Art At 20-Odd Galleries

Williamsburg and Greenpoint are home to more than 20 galleries less than two miles from the Bedford Avenue subway stop, yet visits have not always been easy, because of hidden locations and changeable schedules. On Friday night, the artists will make it easy: during ''Open Williamsburg,'' more than 20 galleries will open their doors to the public.

The spaces vary from museum-style galleries to a pristine shed in a backyard garden, and the participating artists have come from as far as Amsterdam and Tokyo (though most are from Williamsburg). The event is organized in conjunction with Open Source: Networking Artists and Artists Organizations.

''Open Williamsburg''; Friday 6:30 to 8:30 p.m.; the Williamsburg Art Guide will be available at Momenta Art, 72 Berry Street, between North 9th Street and North 10th Street, gallery locations vary; free; (718) 486-8877.
LOWER MANHATTAN Launching a Boat And a Festival

For two months, junior high and high school students from around the city have been building a 19th-century racing boat, a 25-foot, four-oared Whitehall gig (a twin of the one pictured below). The boat has been named the American Star in honor of the boat that defeated a British rival in a harbor race in 1824. The American Star will be launched on Tuesday to kick off the Hudson River Festival, a summerlong series of free music, dance, art and puppetry.
The nightcap to kickoff day is a concert starring Pete Seeger, who will be joined onstage by his grandson, Tao Rodriquez.

Handmade Boat River Launch; Tuesday noon; World Financial Center, Liberty Street and the Hudson River; Pete Seeger concert; Tuesday 7 p.m.; Winter Garden of the World Financial Center, West Street between Vesey and Liberty Streets; both events free; (212) 945-0505.
PROSPECT PARK A Borough Fit for a Celebration
Performers from around the world and around the block will take the stage at the Prospect Park Bandshell in Celebrate Brooklyn! This festival features music, dance, film and the spoken word.
The bandshell, where the festival has been held for 22 seasons, is newly renovated, with seating for 2,000 and lawn seating for 5,000.

The first performer is Susan Tedeschi (pictured at right), a blues singer and guitarist, who received a Grammy nomination for best new artist. Shows continue on weekend nights at 7:30 through the summer; Friday night features Bamboleo and Barbarito Torres, and Saturday night stars Kenny Banks and the Rhythm Makers and Chocolate Genius.
''Celebrate Brooklyn!'' opens Thursday 7:30 p.m.; Prospect Park Bandshell, Ninth Street and Prospect Park West; suggested donation, $3; (718) 855-7882, ext. 45.
ALSO AROUND TOWN

BIKER BABES -- Motorcycles and diapers are an unlikely combination, but the ''Bikers for Babies'' Pamper run requires a diaper donation; riders take a police-escorted route from Brooklyn to Hale House in Harlem; food and festivities are the rewards for donations; meet at 9 a.m. Saturday, depart 11 a.m. from 240 Cook Street, between Bogart Street and Evergreen Avenue, Bushwick; (917) 567-9580.

MAKE IT JAMAICA -- Jamaica, Queens, is more than a place to change trains on the Long Island Rail Road; it is a bustling neighborhood and commercial district; Jack Eichenbaum, urban geographer, will lead a free walking tour Saturday at 10:30 a.m.; meet at Jamaica Market, 159-17 Jamaica Avenue; (718) 526-2422.

TAKING IT TO THE STREETS -- ABC No Rio, a community center for the arts and community issues, celebrates its 20th anniversary with a street fair featuring performance artists, local organizations and vegetarian food; Saturday noon to 6 p.m.; 156 Rivington Street, between Clinton and Suffolk Streets; free; (212) 254-3697.
ALLISON FASS and LIZ MURRAY
